captions.text: You might wonder why humans look the way we do
and how we ended up this way. Well it turns out the things our DNA is left
behind for the past few hundred thousand years
is mind-bogglingly cool.
While it's known that all humans develop a tale in the womb that eventually
dissolves, only the recently we've discovered where it might have come from
in the first place.
The world's most primitive primate whatever early ancestors
dryomomys
szalayi - slazi? slahzee? Spends most of it's life in trees.
which would have been a huge advantage for gathering food compared to other
land dweller some 56 million years ago.
It's very likely that this is how primates rocked it so hard in the animal kingdom.
for most of human evolution, every human head brown eyes.
That is until six to ten thousand years ago a genetic mutation from a single
person near the Black Sea changed
everything. This mutation affected the production of melanin the substance that
determines hair and skin color, and switched the color of the ice from brown
to blue. Somehow it spread across Europe in approximately eight percent of the
world's population has blue eyes. But it also means that every blue-eyed person
may share the same ancestor.
that's..that's kind of weird.  We're not 100 percent sure why we have as little hair on our
bodies as we do
but one theory is that we were finally walking upright in the ridiculously hot
African savanna
you know, evolving and what not, we had to rid ourselves of hair in order to cool
ourselves down.
Our hairlessness might have been seen as a sign of good health, making the less
hairy more attractive to the opposite sex.
Last but not least, before we evolved into humans,
the penises our primate ancestors were covered in hard spines.
Yeah you heard me. Theory suggests that the human males had the spines as a way
of removing the sperm of their competitors.
Which thankfully isn't as big a deal that was thousands of years ago
anyway, after we started more monogamous relationships, it makes sense the less
bumps we had in our penises
the better the sex. The better the sex the more monogamous the relationship.
So as the great Charles Darwin once said and I quote
evolution is totally also awesome.

title: Things Our Bodies Used To Have

comments.author: PrincessKLS

comments.text:
Someone please xplain to me why all blue eyed people having the same 
ancestor is weird. I watched another vid that said the same thing and they 
acted like it was the greatest and most bizare discovery ever. I mean, no 
matter what you believe in, religion or science, at some point there were 
only two of whoever our ancestor/species is. So we are all related, its 
inarguable. Like i really dont get it, how is so weird that all blue eyed 
people share the same ancestor when we ALL share the same ancestor up the 
line. plus, who is to say that the mutation of blue eyes isnt random. They 
are assuming that that one guy who developed blue eyes was the only one. 
How can they know this? Downs Syndrome is a mutation. I dont see people 
sayng all people with Downs share the same ancestor. And what about the 
other eye colors? Green, hazel, even red has been reported in few cases. 
Its random, I really dont see how it means all blue eyed people share ONE 
common ancestor with blue eyes. Mutations are random! Yes, they can become 
traits over time (the fur of polar bears was once a mutation!) and maybe 
that blue eyed person 10,000 years ago was the first one and maybe he did 
pass on his mutation to his desecendants. Big deal. Thats genetics. But 
saying ALL blue eyed people are his ancestor is ignorant. I mean, if he was 
the first one that means he didnt get it from one of his ancestors, which 
proves that a person having blue eyes can either be genetic or just a 
random mutation, as in his case.﻿

If you dont believe me go look up all that evidence that has been

comments.text:
Not really, The mass has enough room for variation that maybe humans as we 
know it wouldn't exist, but other life would. We just seem to think it's 
perfect because it's what we recognize as working. People will always say 
we're perfect mass, perfect distance from the sun, etc. In reality we could 
vary the mass of the earth by a considerable bit and not change it too 
much, and we could push earth all the way to where mars is and we could 
still support life. It's an illusion of perfection, Just because it's what 
humans needed to evolve, it doesn't mean that's what all life needs. And 
another thing, the earth isn't necessarily required to support human life, 
Say the mass was larger and a different race of intelligent life evolved, 
they would say it's perfect for them, if it was any smaller their race 
wouldn't have existed.

comments.author: David Cater

comments.text:
+David Cater Take bone structure for example, we have found skeletons that 
date back thousands of years. Every skeleton has a different shaped head. 
Over time you see how the human brain evolved to be able to create and 
understand language, culture, and leadership. We can tell that they were 
our ancestors by looking at the tools they have created. Some have created 
beads to act as an accessory, or a type of currency. Others have developed 
weapons which allowed them to kill and hunt animals. All of this didn't 
happen in one person's life. But changes in the body that is able to be 
passed down to their offspring is able to create a new species.
comments.author: Matthew Wong

comments.text:
+David Cater Again... evolution does not happen within a lifetime. No, 
monkeys cannot live for centuries, no humans cannot live for centuries. But 
the changes in their genetic makeup will stack up through reproduction. And 
over a course of centuries, if that trait is successful in getting that 
human or animal mates then the difference between the present and the past 
are noticeable.

comments.text:
0:25 https://translate.google.com/#auto/en/szalayi Frederick Sigmund Szalay 
was born in Hungary in 1938. He made major contributions to the literature 
on mammalian evolutionary morphology. The esteem in which he is held by his 
colleagues can be partly measured by the number of species named after 
him: Oklatheridium szalayi, Sinodelphys szalayi, Tatmanius 
szalayi, Jemezius szalayi to name a few. (Mammalian Evolutionary 
Morphology: A Tribute to Frederick S. Szalay
 edited by Eric J. Sargis, Marian Dagosto) there :)﻿
